headline.seo: A Program Helps Baby Boomers Transition to New Careers

docs.lead_paragraph: A program helps baby boomers, who have gone back to full- or part-time work after retiring, transition to new careers.
docs.snippet: A program helps baby boomers, who have gone back to full- or part-time work after retiring, transition to new careers.

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Discovery, Animal Planet) LIFEOprah Winfrey narrates this 11-part nature series, which explores the adaptability and diversity of life on earth -- culling among the 30 million or so animal and plant species here -- from the spectacular to the downright bizarre. Images were captured in high definition using equipment like a ''yogi cam,'' which can track smoothly alongside migrating reindeer and elephants, and an intricate cable rigging that enabled crews to ''fly'' a camera through thousands of monarch butterflies. The survey begins with ''Challenges of Life,'' which explores survival strategies like those of the stalk-eyed fly, which inflates its head to impress females; Kenyan cheetahs who band together to hunt large prey; and monkeys in Brazil that use tools resembling a hammer and anvil to crack nuts. ''Reptiles and Amphibians,'' at 9, shows a pebble toad escaping a tarantula by bouncing down a rock face; a basilisk lizard running on water; a chameleon snatching its prey with its tongue; and the savage hunting techniques of the Komodo dragon. (Above, a sengi on the move.) 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE A discussion of the health care bill gets going with Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin; Representative Deborah Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida; and Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas. It continues with Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina; Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland; Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky; and Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, and with Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline.main: Sampler: Bay Area Home Prices Rise, and San Francisco Fights Proposition 16

docs.abstract: A look at news of interest in the San Francisco Bay Area.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Plan for the University of California to Handle Prison Medicine | The University of California would benefit by taking charge of an overhaul of the state's prison medical system and creating a centralized system of managed care, according to a report by NuPhysicia, a Texas consultant hired by the state. An estimated $12 billion could be saved over the next decade with the plan, which includes allowing doctors to have access to patient information anywhere and also to see patients via video, state officials said. "This is definitely a wholesale reform of the prison health-care system," said Susan Kennedy, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's chief of staff. [The Los Angeles Times]
docs.snippet: A look at news of interest in the San Francisco Bay Area.

headline.main: For Bronx Community Organizer, Work and Life Were One

docs.abstract: Friends and colleagues mourned Megan Charlop, an advocate for social justice who died on Wednesday when her bicycle was struck by a bus.
docs.lead_paragraph: One winter day in the mid-1970s, Jim Buckley, a young tenant organizer in the Bronx, went to the offices of Con Ed to try to get an apartment building's lights turned back on.
docs.snippet: Friends and colleagues mourned Megan Charlop, an advocate for social justice who died on Wednesday when her bicycle was struck by a bus.

headline.main: Food, **. Price, $$$. Cleanliness, a Blue A.

docs.abstract: Also in the Morning Buzz: the principal of the city's only Arabic-language public school steps down; Hiram Monserrate is defeated in his effort to recapture his State Senate seat; and other regional news.
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York City Board of Health voted Tuesday to rate cleanliness in the city's more than 24,000 restaurants with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a controversial plan proposed 14 months ago by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
docs.snippet: Also in the Morning Buzz: the principal of the city's only Arabic-language public school steps down; Hiram Monserrate is defeated in his effort to recapture his State Senate seat; and other regional news.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new rule in New York City schools, which officials say is aimed at tackling obesity, restricts student bake sales.

headline.main: Doctors and Patients, Not Talking About Weight

docs.abstract: Most doctors have no training in weight management and nutrition and can do little to help their obese patients lose weight.
docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors recognize obesity as a health problem. So why is it so hard for them to talk to their patients about it?
docs.snippet: Most doctors have no training in weight management and nutrition and can do little to help their obese patients lose weight.

docs.lead_paragraph: A generic anti-inflammatory drug from the aspirin family helped patients in a clinical trial lower their blood sugar.
